author: avgoTendies
body:
No one is building fabs for these older chips

The shortage will go on for a long time

I work for Broadcom

I know some shit about chips

author: Jundestag
body:
Long term I’d say the chip makers who are best at creating embedded chips. AMD is not one of those.

Everything will be smart and/or robot at some point. And it needs to be very power efficient.

Pc’s will be just a very small percentage of future chip market growth.

So I would bet on asml, tsmc, intel (as a foundry), broadcom, nxp

author: ZheeDog
body: With the Fed and Treasury keeping so much extra cash in the system, real investing has become almost meaningless. Bad companies stay alive with easy money policies and debt issuance, while good ones cannot distinguish themselves due to market distortions caused by fast & easy money chasing the next "surge" stock. And right now, anything worth owning is not price for value whatsoever. For example, take at look at AVGO, APD or ITW - all great companies, all well more than fully priced.

author: Kekbar
body: Stockpile broadcom yesterday during the dip so you get the divvy then sell calls on it

author: pandatears420
body:
In no particular order: AAPL, BOMN, BRK'B, ASML, AVGO

Apple I think will continue to show impressive numbers 10 - 20 years from now.

BOMN, I hope will be the mini Berkshire that people proclaim them to be. So far they have done well with asset allocation.

BRK'B. Berkshire has constantly won and will continue to win. They have something like $140 billion in cash at the moment. That's a lot to play with. They have positions in some really powerful companies. They are boring but that's fine as long as they keep wining. 

ASML has no real competition and will continue to dominate their sector of the market. They are a no brainer investment.

AVGO, probably could put any company in the semiconductor space up here but I like AVGO because all the major players use AVGO's products to manufacture their chips. That ain't changing anytime soon.

author: th3cr1t1c
body:
So AVGO is trading at a 25% premium to fair value.  INTC is trading at a 29% discount to Fair Value.

Using Gordon Growth Model (Dividend Discount Model), Intel's valuation is $22 per share.

That does not make either of these two attractive recommendations at this particular time.  It also is threatened by the expectation of chip shortages to extend into 2022-23 (Morningstar Research) by which time, FOMC action on interest rates may trigger a sell-off in the broader market.

(Source: Am finance data analytics professional with 25 years professional experience and investing experience.)

author: pandatears420
body:
I like AVGO.

And as a related play, I like COHU. They are involved in the production of semiconductors by making testing equipment. It's a riskier play than AVGO and the other big names like TSM, AMD, and so on.

author: Butterscotch-Apart
body: That’s not true. I invested 10k in Broadcom last March and reinvesting the fat dividend has got me up nearly 90% and added around 1.25 shares along way.

author: Draiko
body:
Intel is a bad call. They're going to be in trouble until at least Raptor lake (won't happen for at least another 12 months) and sapphire rapids is already slipping further into 2022. Very bad.

Cisco isn't doing much of anything.

Apple MIGHT have a problem since Samsung's foldables are selling like crazy and I'm seeing a lot of iPhone users making the switch.

nVidia is going to do well long term but there's a risk of a short term dip IF the ARM deal gets blocked.

Microsoft and Broadcom are fine.

You need to add AMD to that list. I know it doesn't meet your criteria but you should not be investing in tech without grabbing some AMD shares.
